setup.question: Why did Maitland get excited about being held hostage?
answers: He thought he could travel to Mars

Text.text: B. I naturally lean towards B because why else who someone be excited to be kidnapped
Maitland is a scientist who gets kidnapped by
. The two are from the future, and Maitland realizes that after Swarts tells him:

. Maitland is excited because this is his chance to travel in space.

Maitland wanting to travel in space is a theme that's repeated many times throughout the story:
When Swarts is interviewing Maitland he says:
After learning he's in the future, Maitland starts daydreaming:
Mars is also specifically mentioned, as Maitland later tells Ching
B provides great evidence. Not really sure how this works :D Pls provide more evidence that Maitland is actually excited.

I've listed pretty much all the points that I could about Maitland being excited regarding space travel and the potential to travel to other planets since he's being held hostage in the far future.

Also, after frustrating one of his captors, Swarts; Swarts tells Maitland

. The questions being those about where he is, what the year is, etc.

Later that evening, Maitland is being described as incredibly excited to learn about all the high-tech stuff in the future:

Could you possibly provide evidence of why A is actually CORRECT and then refute it? Also there has to be more of her being excited. No quoted that is exclaimed or something. Provide more context so I can understand the story I don't wanna end the round so quickly.
A reason that A might be correct is that Swarts performs some tests on Maitland:

The tests consist of Swarts measuring some details about Maitland's physiology while asking him questions and the like. Maitland "passes" those tests in the sense that he completes them and annoys Swarts enough for Swarts to send Ching to answer Maitland's questions (4564-4579).

However, this isn't a reason for Maitland to get excited about *being held hostage* since Maitland doesn't literally "defeat" any tests like he's Indiana Jones or something. Also, he isn't excited about beating the tests but rather learning about the world that he's been taken to and realizing that he's in the future, which isn't the same.
I believe you and I agree with your reasoning as why A isn't correct. One more round give more context around your last quote made in first speech.
Sure, the context of the quote is in the end of the story when he's talking to Swarts' assistant Ching about his wishes to go to Mars. This is near the end of the story, Maitland asks her:

. Since he's in the future he realizes that now humans might have the technological capabilities for space travel. However, Ching mentions that even though the technology is there, people in the future don't have the *desire* to go to space, meaning it hasn't been attempted:

.

In other words, it could be attempted if someone were to really want to travel but the people of the future don't see the reasoning behind it. Maitland, having the desire to travel in space and also being in the future thought he would finally get to fulfill his dreams of space travel.
I believe you and your evidence.
